ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

Column: 995

HIGH OIL PRICES

(Impact on costs of utilities and public transport)

1. Mr Gan Kim Yong asked the Minister for Trade and Industry (a) what impact will the high oil prices have on the costs of utilities and public transport in Singapore; and (b) whether these costs will be passed on to the consumers, and if so, to what extent.

The Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry (Dr Vivian Balakrishnan) (for the Minister for Trade and Industry): Mr Speaker,fuel costs constitute about 10% of public transport operating costs. As such, an increase in oil prices will raise the operating costs of the public transport operators.

As to whether this will translate into fare increases, it will only be known at the next fare review exercise which is scheduled forMay 2005. As of now, the Public Transport Council (PTC) has not yet received any formal indication or application from the public transport operators seeking a fare increase next year. If an application is received, PTC will

Column: 996

take into account the conditions facingthe operators and commuters before making a decision.

Fuel cost makes up about 50% of the cost of electricity. Our fuel sources for power generation are oil and gas, and gas prices in Singapore are indexed to oil prices. An increase in oil prices will thus lead to higher electricity costs. The electricity tariff is reviewed quarterly and reset if necessary, to allow a full pass through of changes in the costs of electricity, including increases in oil prices.

To mitigate the increase in electricity bills, we would like to urge consumers to adopt good energy conservation practices, such as using energy-efficient electrical appliances like fluorescent tubes, choosing the correct capacity of air-conditioner for their needs, and so on.

Mr Gan Kim Yong (Holland-Bukit Panjang): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to ask the Minister, in view of the unemployment rate still on the high side and also there are quite a number of residents who are unable to pay their utilities bills, whether he would consider deferring some of the increases in the utilities fees in time to come when they are due for review.

Dr Vivian Balakrishnan: Mr Speaker, electricity costs are not subsidised in Singapore. We do not subsidise these costs because we do not want to distort the price signals which the subsidised price would have on our economy.

With respect to lower income families who require assistance, we have specific assistance schemes run by the Community Development Councils (CDCs) and by the local community organisations to help these families. Members may be aware of the Rental and Utilities Assistance Scheme for those who are living in rental flats who experience cash

Column: 997

flow problems from time to time. Similarly, for those who live in purchased flats, there is the Interim Financial Assistance Scheme to help them with specific needs which may arise from time to time.Even in the case of public transport, Members may be aware that the public transport operators, together with NTUC Club, SLF and the CDCs, have set aside a sum of $6 million in a public transport fund and this fund is used to help low income families pay for public transport expenses of their school-going children.

In summary, the point is that we do not subsidise these prices but we will customise specific assistance programmes for those segments of our society who need help.

Mr Andy Gan Lai Chiang (Marine Parade): Sir, can the Minister please explain what he means by "gas price is indexed to the oil price", especially when they are from different sources?

Dr Vivian Balakrishnan: Thank you for that question. 97% of our gas comes from Indonesia and 3% from Malaysia. In the market for gas, we entered into long-term contracts which are indexed to oil prices because, in the case of production of electricity, these two fuels are, in a sense, interchangeable. When oil prices go up, because of the nature of the contracts which we have entered into, our gas prices will also go up. Similarly, if oil prices come down, so will our gas prices. This means that, as far as we are concerned, at this point in time, our cost of producing electricity is indexed to the cost of oil although 60% of our electricity production is produced using gas.

Dr Tan Boon Wan (Ang Mo Kio): Sir, I am glad to hear the Minister saying that there are CDC-run schemes to provide support for our needy families. Can I ask

Column: 998

the Minister to request the Government to provide for more money so that the CDCs can do more in supporting all these families?

Dr Vivian Balakrishnan: Thank you for the request. At this point in time, the CDCs are not short of funds to support assistance schemes for specific sectors of our society. Butonthe question of whether or not prices should be subsidised overall, the answer is no. Specific assistance schemes are present and funding is not the limiting factor at this point in time.

Mr Gan Kim Yong: Further clarification and requestfor the Minister, Mr Speaker. I understand that some of the power supply companies do provide instalment plans for residents who are in arrears. That has been very helpful. I would like to ask the Minister whether he could consider reducing the upfront payment that Singapore Power is charging the residents. As I understand it, Singapore Power usually asks for 50% upfront paymentin order for them to qualify for an instalment plan. Can I ask the Minister whether this amount could be reduced to make it easier forthe residents to pay by instalments?

Dr Vivian Balakrishnan: Mr Speaker, I do not want to get involved in the specific details of what is a commercial arrangement between the power retailers and the specific customers concerned. But the point is, so long as the customer is paying and has a realistic plan to pay off and settle his arrears, usually the commercial operator will not take drastic steps. I think Members of this House will agree that the minimum is that they have to at least settle their on-going charges which they are incurring every month because if they do not even settle that, it means that their arrears are going to escalate and they end up in a deep, deep hole which they cannot recover from.

Column: 999

Mdm Ho Geok Choo (West Coast): Sir, I would like to ask the Minister whether, in light of what he has said about not getting involved in the nitty-gritties, he would consider the intervention of the CDCs so that we will have a more robust arrangement in helping these low-income families when they come for assistance with regard to their financial help in this area. This is in relation to Mr Gan Kim Yong's question about some assistance to lower the requirement for the payment before assistance is given.

Dr Vivian Balakrishnan: It is really a repetition of the same question. I think our retailers exercise a considerable amount of forbearance and the key point they want to see is that there is a serious and concerted effort to settle the arrears and not to just allow things to escalate out of hand. If we do that, we are really not doing anyone any favours and, in fact, Members will know that a few years ago, when there were problems with the billing system which resulted in delayed billing of power bills, it actually caused a situation in which households were stuck with huge amounts of arrears whichtook time to clear, both on the part of the households as well as the retailers. So the general principle which I want to emphasise is that power is not subsidised in Singapore.

Secondly, please conserve energy to the maximum extent that you can and, thirdly, make serious efforts to settle your bills, and if you really have difficulties,please seek help from the local community organisations. We do not want to confuse the role of the retailer with the community assistance organisation or with that of the Government either.

Column: 999

UNEMPLOYMENT RATE

2.  Mdm Halimah Yacob asked the Minister for Manpower (a) if he will  give an assessment of the labour market situation; and (b) whether the lower

Column: 1000

unemployment rate of 3.4% for the third quarter is an indication that the job market has improved or is this an aberration as has been suggested by some economists.

3.  Dr Wang Kai Yuen asked the Minister for Manpower what are the reasons behind the sharp drop in the unemployment rate while structural unemployment remains a persistent problem.

4.  Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan asked the Minister for Manpower given the recent significant dip in overall unemployment rate  (a) if he will give a comparison of the unemployment rate of  (i) workers below 45 years of age and those above 45 years of age,  as well as (ii) those who possess tertiary education to those who do not;  and (b) if he will state the success rate of schemes that have been implemented by his Ministry to help the older and less educated workers to find jobs and what other schemes are being considered to help such workers.

     The Minister for Manpower (Dr Ng Eng Hen):  Mr Speaker, Sir, may I have your permission to take Question Nos. 2, 3 and 4 together because they are related?

 

     Mr Speaker:  Yes, please proceed.

     Dr Ng Eng Hen:  Mr Speaker, I have also asked the Clerk of Parliament to circulate one Table* to help me illustrate the employment changes. 

 

  Members have asked for the reasons for the unemployment rate drop in the third quarter of this year.  The labour market typically lags economic performance and this partially explains the improved numbers in the third quarter of 2004. Let me elaborate. Members will easily recall how SARS, starting in April last year, affected all sectors drastically, especially the services sector which accounts for the majority of jobs in Singapore.  If you look at the Table, you will note that in the first half of 2003, in


*Cols. 1149-1150


Column: 1001

the midst of SARS, we lost some 30,000 jobs and if you take into account that each year's new labour entrants into our market is about 32,000, we basically lost in that six months a whole year's worth of jobs for new entrants.   Yet the overall unemployment rate peaked not in June of last year but a quarter later in September 2003 at 5.5%, again illustrating that the labour market typically lags economic performance. 

 

      By September 2003 when the unemployment rate went up to 5.5%, Members would also note that economic recovery was already on its way and net jobs were being created.  In fact, from July 2003 to September 2004, about 60,000 jobs were created.  The last four quarters were particularly strong ranging from 11,000 jobs to the last quarter where we had the strongest employment creation - 16,600 jobs.

 

      But even with strong job growth from September last year, unemployment figures did not improve as the labour market had to "soak up" many who had earlier given up looking for jobs, but now chose to re-enter the improved job market.  This explains why, despite our good economic growth for the first two quarters of this year, our unemployment figures did not improve earlier than the third quarter this year.   The number of workers retrenched by private sector establishments  also eased to 1,700 in the third quarter, the lowest since 1997.   Workers and job seekers have also responded well to new job market demands and have become more realistic and adaptable to take on new jobs.  Another factor for the improving unemployment rate is that the combination of  policy changes which we have instituted, including CPF cuts and wage restructuring, have helped businesses turn around.

 

Column: 1002

      These factors have led to an improved employment situation, for workers across all education and age groups.  As a result, the overall seasonally adjusted unemployment rate fell to 3.4% in September 2004, compared to 5.5% in the same period last year.

                                                                                                                                          


     Members have asked for figures for those aged 45 and Dr Amy Khor has asked for some figures.  Sir, let me give some statistics.   

 

     For residents aged 45 and above, the non-seasonally adjusted unemployment rate was 3.2%.  This is a substantial improvement from the 5.9% compared a year ago.  However, once unemployed, older workers still have greater difficulties finding a job.  Older job seekers were unemployed for 16 weeks on average, compared to 8 weeks for their younger counterparts. 

 

     For workers without tertiary education, these workers also experienced a higher resident unemployment rate of 3.7% compared with 3.2% for those with tertiary education.  Again, there has been a marked improvement for both groups of workers compared to the same period last year.  The duration of unemployment was 12 weeks for those without tertiary education, longer than the 8 weeks for the tertiary educated.

 

     Sir, while we are comforted by the improved job situation, we should reiterate the point that the less skilled workers remain more vulnerable to structural unemployment even as our economy improves.  MOM, therefore, agrees with Members of this House that we should give more assistance to the less skilled workers, especially the more mature workers.  We must help them remain employable or re-enter the job market.

 

     Members of the House have asked for specific figures on how our various

Column: 1003

programmes have worked.  Let me name a few.  As you would recall, we have the People for Jobs Traineeship Programme (PJTP), which is a scheme specifically for workers above 40 years of age.  Nearly 20,000 older workers have benefited from PJTP since it was launched in November 2001.  In addition, for Place and Train programmes, 41% were for workers aged 40 and above.

 

     The People for Jobs Traineeship Programme lapses at the end of this year. MOM is working with NTUC and the CDCs to re-focus our energies to help the less skilled workers adapt and remain employable. New programmes will be announced in due course.

 

     Sustained economic growth should lead to further employment growth.  However, we still need to be wary of a slowdown in the global economy due to higher oil prices.  Even so, unemployment rate is likely to end the year at, or slightly, below 4%. 

 

     My Ministry would provide more details in the Third Quarter Labour Market Report to be released on 15th December 2004.

     Mr Leong Horn Kee (Bishan-Toa Payoh):  Sir, I have two questions to ask the Minister.  If I could refer him to the Table that he had just circulated, I would like to ask him that in the fourth quarter of 2003, first quarter of 2004, as well as the second quarter of 2004, there had been positive employment changes in each of these quarters.  But I see that the unemployment rate has remained the same - 4.5% for each of the quarter.  Could the Minister explain to us why there is no change, whereas in the third quarter of 2004 there was a sharp drop from 4.5% to 3.4%?

 

     My second question is to ask the Minister whether he would foresee that, with continued economic growth, there

Column: 1004

would be a continuing improvement in the unemployment rate? 

     Dr Ng Eng Hen:  Sir, I have explained the changes that Mr Leong had asked for, but let me go back to the Table.  The reason is that there is a lag between economic growth and job creation.  Even when jobs were created, we have to soak up those who have left the labour market.  To understand labour market statistics, you have to understand the denominator, which is the Labour Force Participation Rate.  If one chooses not to be looking for work, then he would not be counted in the denominator.  When the job market gets better, many people start looking for jobs, and that grows the denominator.  So, even if you have more jobs, and you have more people employed, your unemployment rate may not shift and, therefore, you would notice it from the statistics that we have generated.

 

     I have asked my staff to change from focusing on "unemployment" to "employment change", which is a more accurate start.  We really want to see whether our economy could add jobs because the denominator shift is based on definition, but in terms of employment growth, the number of jobs in the economy is a discrete number which people could better analyse and see.  And, if you look at our labour market statistics for employment change, it is quite encouraging.  It tells us that our economic fundamentals and labour market policies had been correct, because in the last quarter, we have now about 2.17 million people who are employed, which is the highest number for the last three years.  And the fact that even during SARS, many of our sectors were devastated, our economy bounced back very quickly.  Again, it gives us good reasons to be confident of our economic fundamentals and the changes that we undertook during those difficult periods.  And these, as Members would remember,

Column: 1005

were the CPF cuts as well as the wage restructuring and other aspects.

 

     Mr Leong also asked how we project further growth.  Again, let me reiterate the point that the greatest factor for job creation is good economic growth, not rigidity and protective aspects in the job market.  This had been a very striking lesson, even with the ups and downs of our economic performance over the last five years.  But let us assume, and you have to assume some figure, that GDP is 3-5%, that would generate enough jobs for each year's new labour entrants.  But there is an area of concern.  Even if we have enough jobs, as many people have rightly pointed out, there would be some workers, especially those who are less skilled, mature worker who are displaced and who have a skills mismatch in terms of our new economic restructuring, the types of jobs that we are creating,  that we now want to focus on in terms of our assistance and training programmes, to help them remain employable or to help them to return to the employment market if they are retrenched.  This is a big challenge.   I estimate this to be 1-2% of the resident workforce and we would need a combination of measures, as well as the help of all agencies, grassroots agencies and MPs explaining to these vulnerable workers the importance of skill upgrading to remain employable.  

     Mdm Halimah Yacob (Jurong):  I would like to ask the Minister: of this 3.4% unemployment figure, how many percent comprise those who are structurally unemployed and, additionally, what are the programmes that could be put in place to assist them, other than the ones that the Minister had just described?

 

     The second question that I would like to ask is:  of the 16,000 jobs created, 57% are jobs created in the services sector and largely in the sectors like IT,

Column: 1006

banking, financial services and so on, what kind of jobs would be available for workers who are lesser skilled, despite all the retraining that they have undergone?  There is also a trend where there are now huge increases in jobs of cleaners, but I do not think that is the only job that we want to create for those who are not tertiary educated.

     Dr Ng Eng Hen:  Mdm Halimah has asked what percentage of the 3.4% of the unemployed would consist of those we term  as "structurally unemployed".  Once you are structurally unemployed, you fall out of the labour market.  So that is not a good proxy.  A better proxy in the transit would be "long-term unemployed", which means that someone who has been looking for a job, is still looking for a job, and is unable to find another job for six months. 

 

     There are two interesting factors from our labour statistics.  Last year, when we had an unemployment rate of 5.5%, the long-term unemployment rate jumped up to about 1.7%.  Normally, it is 0.3%, a very small proportion of our resident workforce but this quarter it had dropped back to about 0.8%.  So it is halved.  So what the figures tell us is that when there is good economic growth and job creation, even though some of the jobs do require skills, our workers can respond and our labour market is able to absorb them.  So I think we should continue in our efforts in terms of getting our fundamentals right, making sure that our labour market is flexible and that our businesses have the flexibility to respond, right-size or up-size, when business condition has improved.  That is fundamental.

     Order for Second Reading read.

     The Senior Minister of State for Home Affairs (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

 

Introduction

 

     Sir, Singapore is a small country with limited resources.  The presence of immigration offenders, such as illegal immigrants and overstayers, poses a serious social problem, and compromises our safety and security.  MHA has taken, and will continue to take, a tough stance against all immigration offenders as well as anyone who harbours, employs or assists them to enter or remain unlawfully in Singapore.

     The Immigration Act regulates the entry, stay and exit of foreigners into and out of Singapore.  This Bill amends the Act to enhance the Immigration and Checkpoints Authority's (ICA) operational powers to tackle the immigration offender problem.

 

The immigration offender situation

 

     The widespread publicity on the harbouring of immigration offenders has helped to raise public awareness of the problem.  Through our public education efforts like Crime Watch and the circulation of information leaflets, as well as media publicity on the tough sentences meted out to harbourers, the public is well-aware of our tough stance on the harbouring of immigration offenders.  Our concerted efforts have resulted in a 40% drop of harbourers arrested, from 527 in the year 2000, to 333 last year.

 

     Sir, this drop is a result of the measures taken over the past four to five years.  Our efforts have, therefore, borne fruit.  While we arrested some 16,500 illegal immigrants and overstayers in 2000, this number fell to 11,900 last year, a drop of almost 30% over three years.  But we cannot be complacent.

 

      In strengthening our multi-pronged approach to deal with the supply and demand of immigration offenders, MHA has reviewed the Immigration Act to ensure that the current provisions remain relevant. This amendment Bill is a result of this review.  Let me now elaborate on the key amendments.

 

Harbouring of immigration offenders

      Sir, when the due diligence requirements were introduced more than 10 years ago in 1993, the clearly spelt out

      We have previously informed the House that the police and ICA have in place a set of internal guidelines to determine whether landlords caught for harbouring immigration offenders should be charged in court.  Over the years, we have constantly reviewed and finetuned these guidelines to ensure their relevance and effectiveness.  Consequently, between 2000 and 2003, about half of the harbourers arrested were prosecuted while the rest were issued with a stern warning.  Those prosecuted, if convicted, faced mandatory imprisonment of six months or more.

 

     Given the seriousness of the harbouring offence, we will retain the current mandatory jail sentence to provide a clear deterrence to and aid the prosecution of defiant or recalcitrant offenders who knowingly or recklessly harbour immigration offenders.

 

     What is new in these amendments is that those found guilty of negligently harbouring an immigration offender will not face mandatory imprisonment.  This will, therefore, bridge the gap in the current Act where the prosecution either has to prosecute offenders for an offence that carries a mandatory imprisonment sentence, or let them off with a stern warning.  Also, the courts will have some leeway not to have to send an offender to jail, if found guilty.

 

     Clause 19 of the Bill amends section 57 of the Act by introducing a graduated dual-limb penalty structure for the harbouring offence.  Those charged with

"reckless harbouring" must show that they have conducted any two of the three due diligence checks or furnish other evidence to support their claims that they did not recklessly harbour the immigration offender.  If the court is satisfied that the accused had not acted with reckless disregard, or, if the prosecution decides at the outset that that is the proper charge to prefer in the first place, the offender would face a charge of "negligent harbouring" where the accused must then show that he has conducted all the three due diligence checks or provide other evidence to prove that he had not negligently harboured the immigration offender.  In other words, if a landlord has conducted only two of the due diligence checks, he is liable to be found guilty of negligent harbouring, which does not carry a mandatory jail sentence.  If a landlord conducts only one of the three due diligence checks, he may be charged under either the negligent or reckless limb, depending on the circumstances of the case.

Other amendments

      Sir, in conclusion, these amendments will enable us to more effectively tackle the immigration offender problem and to facilitate immigration officers in carrying out their duties.
